content.description: Crux is off the deck. Big move to good crimp. Then climb the sloppers to the top.
content.location: Just right of yoyo boy. Left hand under cling right on a side pull crimp. Squeeze start with large rock at your back.

content.description:
Perfect power moves on immaculate stone, finishes on a great jug hold. Sit start with left hand on a  low, broken gaston that feels a little too low. Start right hand on a low sloper side pull.

Then you slap up right, use the amazing crimp on the face left, and use a touch of dynamism to snag the finish hold.

This boulder is pure and beautiful movement. Spectacular, with a unique move or two on it. It's one of my favorites at Moes.
content.location:
On the opposite side of the Monkey Boy, v3, on the same boulder. Walk around the lower corner, up the little hill, and you will find that on the right side of the face, there is a series of slopers, a crimp, and a big jug at about 7-8 feet. Sit down in the dirt, and work your way to the top.

The lower you start, the more likely you are getting full value for the difficulty. The most obvious start to me seems to be on the lowest of three sloper holds on the right side.

content.description: Creaky holds on the right side of the sunny Monkey Boy face. The holds are fun, but they are all pretty hollow, and feel like they could rip off at any second. Power through the tough start move, and then tread carefully to the top.
content.protection: I'd take a couple of pads for this one
content.location: Right side of the Monkey Boy sunny face, downhill.

content.description: An awkward sit start to a large pocket. Climb up and trend slightly left and finish above.
content.protection: A few thin pads, landing is uneven.
content.location: A few feet to the right of Dead Rabbit on the same boulder on an obvious chalked crimp rail.

content.description:
beautiful problem on a 45 degree overhanging face. an overall classic in the area.

Sit start double undercling, work through underclings to throw to lip and top out.
content.location: just up the hill from the monkey boy boulder.

content.description:
Sit-start on Indolence (matched in the hueco) and climb the first couple moves on Indolence to the jug. Then, move left into the finish of Pocket Pool.

v4 or v5? Either way, it's the best climbing of Indolence into the best climbing of Pocket Pool.
content.location: Monkey Boy boulder, starting on Indolence, finishing on Pocket Pool

content.description: Fun sloppers over a bulge
content.location: Southeast of Kung Pao boulder (see Moe's Valley guide book !)

content.description: Sit start, then left on flakes, then straight up
content.location: Just right of "Is this good"

content.description:
Cool climbing! There are a couple of nice problems in the corridor leading back from the Man Cave that are worth doing, if you like somewhat sandy, technical little numbers.

First variation is to start on the left using the super cool pinch, and then stand up and do a technical topout on friable edges. v1

Second variation is to grab the two iron crimps (gently) on the right side, and stand up to the lip, top out with more difficulty. v2

Third variation is to add a sit start on the right side, and link into each of the two problems. The one on the left becomes v2ish, and the one on the right becomes v3 or v4? Tough to tell, but they are both fun.

I am using the name from the guidebook to describe this boulder, but really there's just the name and a difficult to follow description (no offense meant), with a number on the map. So if I have this wrong, let me know, and I'll fix it.
content.location: Find Sichuan Peppercorn/Kung Pao, and then look behind you and find the Man Cave. Follow the boulder back right, and look for these nice lines on the left. You'll spot a chalked up pinch at 6 feet, and a low sit on the right with some chalk to orient you.

content.description: Great movement with an awesome high undercling reach to good holds. Spectacular movement to good holds at the top.
content.location: Start low and left on good holds, work a few holds to the right, and then up through long reaches and a really cool undercling move at the top.

content.description: Sit start on the rail, move up and left to side pull and pocket before throwing for the lip and mantling
content.location: Up the hill from monkey boy boulder. Right of Underboy

content.description: Sit start up overhang.
content.location: Left overhang as you approach the boulder

content.description: Good holds with a couple of good reaches on the butt end of the Monkey Boy boulder. One of the best lines on the boulder.
content.location: Around the corner to the right of the sunny Monkey Boy boulder.

content.description: Start on an undercling. Move up a series of sidepulls and crimps. The top out is a little tricky. I used a beach whale approach. Others will surely send with better style.
content.location: On the south face of Monkey Boy boulder. If you are approaching from the Tee Pee Area, this is the first boulder you will encounter. This problem starts on right side of the boulder with an undercling.

content.description: Sit start on opposing jug sidepulls. Move up through a series of sloping right facing huecos. The first 1 or 2 moves is the crux and can be accomplished in a variety of ways.
content.location: Just up the hill Monkey Boy and around the corner from Underboy on the other very large boulder.

content.description: There's a really cool looking cave, with what looks like a traverse out of the cave, then low, then up the right side of the mouth on a blunt arete. Unfortunately, there just aren't many fun holds, and there is a lot of sand. It would take a very thorough cleaning of all the sand to make this a little more climbable. As it is, this little v3 starts nearly outside the cave, and shoots up the arete, constituting the grade with a big move or smaller moves on a small crimp.
content.location: Right side of the cave facing Kung Pao/Sichuan Peppercorn.

content.description: Stand start on holds above your head and make a big move. A heady top out awaits.
content.location: 15 feet left of Greased Lightning on the boulder just above Underboy.

content.description: A low start to Bazooka Tooth Direct. Start as for Grenadine on jugs way back in the cave and make a few moves on that problem before moving right through the roof toward the start of Bazooka Tooth Direct using a cool patina pocket, a variety of foot trickery and some brutal compression and finish with the dyno on BTD. Very sandy rock (that may clean up and solidify with more ascents) but awesome continuous and difficult movement that adds a lot to the BTD dyno.
content.location: Same start as Grenadine on the Bazooka Tooth boulder, far back in the cave on the left.

content.description: Sit start with crimps. Throw to the jug above, traverse left, and finish up Sichuan Peppercorn.
content.location: Starts right of Sichuan Peppercorn

content.description:
Fun little climb on the backside of the Man Cave boulder. Hike around, trying to be gentle with the flora, and find a cool pillar sculpted into the rock by two huecos at about 6-7 feet.

We found a few variations in here.

Starting standing on left is a nice line with a cool topout. v0/1

Starting standing right is also good, with a more difficult topout. v1/2

Sit start on the left is tricky/awkward, but when you do it right, it actually feels really good. You can use that to go straight up to the left hueco into a rad sloper and finish straight up. I'd say this is how we justify v3.

The next variation is to SS left, and finish up and right. The SS is the hard part, and you get to do the more technical finish. v3/+.

Climb gingerly, some of these features are a little fragile.
content.protection: 2 pads is nice for uneven landing.
content.location: Back side of the Man Cave boulder, which is in Monkey Boy area - start by finding Sichuan Peppercorn/Kung Pao, look behind you and see the disappointing Man Cave. Then walk around right of the boulder until you find two cool huecos back there, forming a little pillar. Fun abounds.

content.description: Sit start, go up right with flakes, then straight up.
content.location: Right of the southwest arete.

content.description: Start matched in small hueco, move up and right towards massive jug/bucket on right, use small crimps to the top.
content.protection: Crash pads. Gnarly unexpected falls are possible on this one. landing is perfect though.
content.location: When you get to moes hike down the was and bear right. Continue to follow the wash until you are in the valley. Continue down that wash and it should be the first bold you come to. this problem can be found on the north east side of the monkey boy boulder.

content.description: Super fun power endurance problem and really adds to the overall climb.
content.location: Sit start on the low crimp rail far left from the original indolence start. Traverse the rail to a big move into the indolence jug then get your heel up. From here you are into indolence

content.description:
One of the best boulder problems I have ever seen. One of the best, if not THE best boulder problem in Moe's Valley.

Start on lowest, crimpy rail. Go up and left through perfect slopers with a powerful heel hook on a slightly overhanging face.
content.protection: A couple of pads and a spotter.
content.location: This boulder is located on the hillside overlooking the Monkey Boy area. A trail leads up the hill directly to the boulder

content.description: Start on giant holds and do a juggy lip traverse and top out just left of the out for Bazooka Tooth.   Not the proudest line in Moe's, but it could work as a fresh warm up if you've done all the others.
content.location: Arete on the left side of Bazooka Tooth boulder

content.description: Sit start on undercling. Move up big flake and top out.
content.location: To the right of Man-Boy. Up the Hill from Monkey Boy boulder.

content.description: The best and hardest problem on the sunny Monkey Boy face. Grab the big holds, work your feet high, grab a tough left side pull, and commit. Good topout.
content.protection: a couple pads, and a spotter
content.location: Middle of Monkey Boy downhill face. Start in the big holds in the middle of the face.

content.description: Avoid traversing right by using small crimps and shallow pockets.  Make a big pull to large pockets under the lip on left side of cave. One last big pull to the right brings you back to Angel wings' topout.
content.location: Same start as Angel wings

content.description: Same sit start as for White Rabbit on the obvious crimp rail several feet right from Dead Rabbit.
content.protection: A few thin pads, landing is uneven.
content.location: A few feet to the right of Dead Rabbit on the same boulder on an obvious chalked crimp rail.

content.description:
About 50 yards west of the Monkey Boy boulder two boulders are stacked next to each other, one of which has a striking black face with a hueco at the base and a big jug just below the top. This is Dead Rabbit.

Start matched in the hueco (kneebar helpful) and work up and right on good but small crimps to the jug. Top out from there. Excellent rock, close to Joe's Valley in quality.
content.protection: A couple of pads would be smart as the landing is rocky in places

content.description: Sit start on crimps (the big block on the ground to your right is on for your right foot).  Fire up into a big bucket jug, then continue straight up the bulge using the fins on top of it.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter.  The landing is nice and flat and the boulder is not very tall (maybe 9 - 10 feet).
content.location: This problem starts the same as Kung Pao on the south face of a distinct boulder with tufa and scoop features on it.

content.description: Climb edges to big move
content.location: Just right of pterodactyl

content.description:
The direct line of Bazooka Tooth. Sit start on slopey underclings and a kneebar. Make a few difficult moves straight out of the cave, then throw big to a juggy hueco and finish with an easy topout.

Stemming the right wall is off route.
content.location: Bazooka Tooth boulder. Keep walking past Monkey Boy boulder about 100 feet.

content.description:
Not the proudest line compared to its neighbors, but fun movement, height, and a short crux makes this a fun and easily protected climb. Like most V6 and harder boulder problems at Moe's, Bazooka Tooth becomes easier if you can reach through. That said, this is mostly a power climb that tests core and shoulder strength.

Start on the undercling deep in the cave. Power stem and gaston your way out to a good horizontal crimp rail, bear down and try not to dab as you transition your weight. Move up and right, make a counter clockwise spin to the glory jug, and top out. The line is pretty obvious.
content.protection: 1-2 pads.  Use your thinnest pad to protect the crux; dab city around there.

content.description: Sit start on small holds at left of cave traverse on bad crimps going right low to the ground. At side pull move up onto good rail then out roof.  Good topout. For a v4-5 start on the Side pull.
content.location: Steep boulder touching Kung pao's walk off.

content.description:
Rad movement on a beautiful black wall start us out here. Start hugging the slightly overhanging shield of rock, and compress your way to a nice jug at head height or so. Then cut right onto sandy edges, and do a miserable topout to the left of Dead Rabbit's, with a rock to your back that most people will probably scrape up to finish bc it's so close. The sit start on the black shield is amazing on this, and the black eye of it is the topout. I'd say it's still worth the effort.

Take it easy with chalk, this rock will make it stand out brightly.
content.location: To the left of Dead Rabbit, find a black shield of bullet hard rock.
